Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Terahertz Micro-Nanoscopy: A Pathway to the Integration of Terahertz Photonics

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Objective: The objective of this research project is to design and establish the device foundations for a Terahertz Micro-Nanoscope capable of submicron resolutions. The proposed approach is based on the demonstration of compact THz photonic devices and the integration to achieve a near-field imaging system that can successfully image submicron-scale individual structures such as a single cell, while probing their spectral and spatial characteristics. More compact and user-friendly components are key to enabling the envisioned THz micro-nanoscope and ensuring it can be widely used or adopted in the future.
Intellectual Merit: The intellectual merit of the proposed CAREER program stems from the investigation of a new paradigm of interaction between light and matter to attain combined spectroscopic sensing and near-field imaging capabilities by utilizing THz waves, which originate from a portion of the electromagnetic spectrum that has not been fully utilized to date. The new, transformative device foundation is based on the use of nitride semiconductor materials and nanostructures that can enable more compact THz photonics systems, and thus push the limits of imaging currently available in a wide range of fields.
Broader Impact. The broader impact of the research will be in facilitating the development of THz-based diagnostic tools to fight against diseases. This work will be integrated with education and outreach activities (including K-12) aimed at increasing the participation of women and students from underrepresented groups in science and engineering. Planned collaborations with industry will ensure the proposed research can more easily lead to commercial applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: This project is aimed at designing and establishing the device foundations for a Terahertz Micro-Nanoscope capable of submicron resolutions, which would enable a new paradigm of interaction between light and matter by attaining combined spectroscopic sensing and near-field imaging capabilities.  A near-field microscope has been integrated into a THz TDS system. To aim the compact system, we proposed and developed nanowire based THz sources, which potentially remove bias voltage. One of the proposed work is to explore metamaterials based THz devices. A number of THz metamaterial multilayer absorber structures have been designed and simulated, fabricated and tested. We achieved 1) polarization insensitive THz metamaterials absorber for sensors, 2) polarization selective THz metamaterials absorber devices for sensors, 3) THz plasmonic induced transparency devices for high sensitivity and selectivity of the sensors, 4) electrically tunable THz devices to increase bandwidth and selectivity of the sensors. All our devices can be integrated current THz Micro-Nanoscope to increase the performance and broadening the application from materials characterization to biosensing.

Broader Impact: The broader impact of the research will be in facilitating the development of THz-based diagnostic tools to fight against diseases.  This work will be integrated with education and outreach activities (including K-12) aimed at increasing the participation of women and students from underrepresented groups in science and engineering.  Planned collaborations with industry will ensure the proposed research can more easily lead to commercial applications.

Through developing and conducting this research project, 3 doctoral students were granted their PhD degree in the area of THz technology for sensing and imaging. (Dr. Wilbert (2015), Dr. Hokmabadi (2016), Dr. Balci (2017)) Currently 3 graduate students are working toward for their PhD for this research field, and among them two are female graduate students. In addition, 3 MS theses were completed. Through this CAREER project, total 20 undergraduates were participated in this project through either REU supplements or other types of scholarship/internship support. Among them, four were female undergraduates and 7 were from under represented minorities including Hispanics,  12 students chose to continue their research and entered the graduate school, epically 2 students received multiple fellowship/scholarship including NSF Graduate Research Fellowship (Bolus, Lukens), National Defense Science and Engineering Graduate Scholarship (Lukens). 1 student was finalist of Goldwater scholar (Bolus), and 1 student was recipient of Randall Outstanding Undergraduate Research Award (Maleski).

Publications/Products: The research has led to 13 peer-reviewed journal articles, 20 refereed conference proceedings.
